chapter.title: Built In DataTypes, Classes, Interfaces and Stereotypes

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter describes the datatypes, classes, interfaces and stereotypes, which by default, are built in to &argouml;.

Datatypes, classes and interfaces are generally available for use anywhere a class may be selected in the properties tab. The most common use is for return type and parameter types in method signatures.

sect2.title: Package Structure
sect2.para: &argouml; datatypes, classes and interfaces are effectively organized as a hierarchy beneath the overall model itself. They are grouped in four packages, lang, math, net and util, themselves subpackages of java, which is a subpackage of the model itself. shows this structure.

sect2.title: Exposure in the model
sect2.para: You will not find build-in DataTypes, Classes, and Interfaces exposed within the model by default (i.e. they are not present in the explorer). However, once you select one of the built-in DataTypes, Classes, or Interfaces (in the "Type" combo-box on the property sheet of a parameter of an operation of a class), then it becomes visible: you will find that the DataType, Class, or Interface has appeared in the model, in its correct package stucture for the latter 2.

sect1.title: Built In Datatypes
sect1.para: These are the built in atomic types. You can change them if you wish. However this is not good practice.
All these can be found in the java.lang subpackage of the main model.

caution.para: You should be aware that these are Java datatypes. They are not mandated by the UML standard.

sect1.para: These are the standard datatypes. For their definition refer to the Java standard.

note.para: void is not strictly speaking a type, but the absence of type. &argouml; knows about void and allows it as an option where a datatype may be selected.

sect1.title: Built In Classes
sect1.para: These are the common classes, corresponding to classes defined within the standard Java environment. It is up to you if you wish to change them.
These are found in all four subpackages of the java subpackage.
For a definition of these classes see the Java language and library definitions.

sect2.title: Built In Classes From java.lang
sect2.para: These are the classes within the java.lang package.

sect2.title: Built In Classes From java.math
sect2.para: These are the classes within the java.math package.

sect2.title: Built In Classes From java.net
sect2.para: These are the classes within the java.net package.

sect2.title: Built In Classes From java.util
sect2.para: These are the classes within the java.util package.

sect1.title: Built In Interfaces
sect1.para: These are some useful interfaces, corresponding to classes defined within the standard Java environment. Interfaces have many of the properties of classes (like all types) and you can change them if you wish.
All these can be found in the java.util subpackage of the main model.
These are the interfaces defined within the java.util package. For their definition consult the Java language and library references.

chapter.sect1:
Built In Stereotypes
¬updatedfor014disclaimer;
UML 1.3 defines a large number of stereotypes which are (mostly) supported by &argouml;. In addition &argouml; defines three additional stereotypes that may be of use.
machine. Available to artifacts derived from the top level UML metaclass, Element.
person. Available to artifacts derived from the top level UML metaclass, Element.
organization. Available to artifacts derived from the UML metaclass ModelElement.
Not all stereotypes defined by UML 1.3 appear in &argouml;, due to limitations in the current implementation of some artifacts.
